thread.title: Washington DC Airports could be for sale in Trump infrastructure plan

author: Leslie Josephs
title: Washington DC Airports could be for sale in Trump infrastructure plan
text:
Getty Images Passengers at Washington Dulles International Airport. 
Do you find 13,000 acres of prime real estate in the Washington, D.C. area, complete with a Burberry shop and Starbucks cafes appealing? 
Such a for-sale advertisement for two of Washington, D.C.'s main area airports may pop soon. The Trump administration on Monday said it is considering selling Washington Dulles International Airport and Ronald Reagan International Airport along with other federally-owned infrastructure. 
"Federal ownership of these assets can result in sub-optimal investment decisions and create risk for taxpayers," said the Trump administration's infrastructure proposal . "To utilize this authority, an agency would delineate how proceeds would be spent and identify appropriate conditions under which sales would be made." 
The airports are among pieces of infrastructure "that would be more appropriately owned by State, local, or private entities," the administration said. 
Unlike in Europe, most U.S. airports are publicly owned, usually by local governments, but the federal government owns these two Washington-area airports. 
"I think of privatization as having two potential objectives: one is to monetize an existing asset, or more colloquially: cash out," said Samuel Engel, head of the aviation practice at consulting firm ICF. "The other is to tap the capital markets to build and invest in infrastructure." 
While outright private ownership is rare, unlike in other regions like Europe, millions of flyers in the United States have experienced a structure where private companies, including airlines, operate terminals . 
As their lifeblood, airlines often have to agree to major changes in airport ownership structure, Engel said. "The airlines are not likely to support a deal that would result in higher charges." 
While it's too early to tell who would step forward as a buyer, another selling point: Record passenger traffic worldwide. Each of these airports handled more than 21 million passengers in 2016, according to Airports Council International, an industry group.
